name: continuant
def: An entity that exists in full at any time in which it exists at all, persists through time while maintaining its identity and has no temporal parts.

name: occurrent
def: An entity that has temporal parts and that happens, unfolds or develops through time.

name: independent continuant
def: b is an independent continuant = Def. b is a continuant which is such that there is no c and no t such that b s-depends_on c at t. (axiom label in BFO2 Reference: [017-002])

name: process
def: p is a process = Def. p is an occurrent that has temporal proper parts and for some time t, p s-depends_on some material entity at t. (axiom label in BFO2 Reference: [083-003])

name: realizable entity
def: A specifically dependent continuant  that inheres in continuant  entities and are not exhibited in full at every time in which it inheres in an entity or group of entities. The exhibition or actualization of a realizable entity is a particular manifestation, functioning or process that occurs under certain circumstances.

name: specifically dependent continuant
def: b is a specifically dependent continuant = Def. b is a continuant & there is some independent continuant c which is not a spatial region and which is such that b s-depends_on c at every time t during the course of b’s existence. (axiom label in BFO2 Reference: [050-003])

name: role
def: A realizable entity  the manifestation of which brings about some result or end that is not essential to a continuant  in virtue of the kind of thing that it is but that can be served or participated in by that kind of continuant  in some kinds of natural, social or institutional contexts.

name: material entity
def: An independent continuant that is spatially extended whose identity is independent of that of other entities and can be maintained through time.

name: living tissue
def: Unfixed fully hydrated tissue, typically employed to monitor dynamic changes in the living state.

name: eosin
def: Staining with an aqueous or alcoholic solution of eosin Y,colors eosinophilic structures in various shades of red, pink and orange. The eosinophilic structures are generally composed of intracellular or extracellular protein. The Lewy bodies and Mallory bodies are examples of eosinophilic structures. Most of the cytoplasm is eosinophilic. Red blood cells are stained intensely red.

name: hematoxylin
def: The staining method involves application of hemalum, which is a complex formed from aluminium ions and oxidized haematoxylin. This colors nuclei of cells (and a few other objects, such as keratohyalin granules) blue. The staining of nuclei by hemalum does not require the presence of DNA and is probably due to binding of the dye-metal complex to arginine-rich basic nucleoproteins such as histones. The mechanism is different from that of nuclear staining by basic (cationic) dyes such as thionine or toluidine blue. Staining by basic dyes is prevented by chemical or enzymatic extraction of nucleic acids. Such extractions do not prevent staining of nuclei by hemalum.

name: intracellular filling
def: visualization of the connected regions of a cell by filling with a label

name: tissue in vitreous ice embedment
def: Fully hydrated tissue rapidly frozen to produce vitrified water, and maintained continuously below the glass transition temperature of water (approximately -137 deg C

name: permeabilized tissue
def: Tissue treated to make cell membranes permeable, typically for the purpose of allowing access by exogenous stains or substrates.

name: vizualization of label conjugated to probe
glycerol permeabilized
def: tissue made permeable by the action of glycerol

name: primary antibody plus labeled secondary antibody
macroscopy
def: methods for imaging objects large enough to be observed by the unaided eye

name: microscopy
def: methods for forming images of objects too small to be observed with the unaided eye

name: dark-field microscopy
def: imaging with rejection of the unscattered illumination (removal of the zero order component of the diffracted wave)

name: scanning electron microscopy (SEM)
def: image is formed by scanning the surface of the specimen with a beam of electrons in a raster pattern

name: atomic force microscopy
def: the scanning probe is maintained at a fixed distance above the surface e of the specimen by van der Waals forces

name: detergent permeabilized
def: Membrane permeabilization by the action of ionic or non-ionic detergents

name: solvent permeabilized
def: permeabilization due to extraction of lipid from membranes by an organic solvent such as acetone or methanol.

name: saponin permeabilized
def: Saponin, a detergent-like molecule, preferentially forms holes in membranes that contain cholesterol.

name: recorded image
def: methods and devices used for capturing an image of a real object; distinct from images created by artwork

name: portrayed image
def: methods and devices used for creating images by some form of artwork, as distinct from capturing images by means of some recording device

name: animation
def: A form of graphical illustration that changes with time to give a sense of motion or represent dynamic changes in the portrayal.

name: illumination method
def: sources and methods for illumination

name: detection method
def: media and devices employed for recording the alterations in the illumination that result from its interaction with the sample

name: imaged parameter
def: The physical property of the specimen that leads to the modifications of the illumination that are recorded in the image.

name: widefield illumination
def: illumination that covers the entire field of view of the image-forming lens

name: narrowfield illumination
def: illumination restricted to a small portion of the field of view of the imaging lens; often one or more diffraction limited spots

name: pulsed illumination
def: illumination that varies with time; often achieved with pulsed lasers for the purpose of generating very-high peak illumination power

name: single point scanning
def: illumination by a single spot of light that is scanned across the field of view

name: multiple point scanning
def: illumination by multiple points of light simultaneously

name: spinning disk scanning
def: scanning by multiple points of light arising from pinholes in a spinning disk that is illuminated by a widefield source

name: array scanning
def: Multiple points of illumination generated by a fixed array of sources.

name: hollow-cone illumination
def: illumination parallel or at small angles to the optical axis is attenuated or blocked by a stop

name: anaxial illumination
def: Illumination is distributed asymmetrically around the optic axis, typically achieved by a non-circular stop placed below the lower lens element and aperture of the condenser.

name: darkfield illumination
def: illumination restricted to angles that exceed the acceptance angle of the image-forming lens

name: Rheinberg illumination
def: illumination at angles less than the acceptance angle of the image-forming lens is attenuated by a filter to give a colored background of unscattered light; higher angle illumination may be filtered to give a contrasting color

name: fluorescence polarization (polarization angle resolved fluorescence emission)
resolution-enhancing method
def: methods for increasing the resolution beyond the classical Abbe diffraction limit

name: Wollaston prism
def: a birefringent optical element typically used to split polarized illumination into two sets of parallel but displaced rays

name: FIONA (fluorescence imaging with one nanometer accuracy)
PAINT (point accumulation for imaging in nanoscale topography)
saturated structured-illumination microscopy (SSIM)
def: structured illumination used at sufficiently high power to cause significant ground-state depletion of the imaged fluorophore, thus allowing for non-linear resolution enhancement

name: scanning probe microscopy
def: imaging by means of a physical probe that passes over the sample

name: ANSOM
def: Aperture-less NSOM.

name: modified objective lens
def: Uses an objective with extra components to manipulate the wave front in the plane of the objective aperture.

name: linear method
def: a computational method that is linear in the mathematical sense, meaning that image intensity is conserved and the data remain suitable for all quantitative analyses

name: non-linear method
def: computational method that are mathematically non-linear; image intensity is not conserved, and the data are in general not suitable for quantitative analyses of pixel values

name: light-sheet illumination
def: illumination in the form of a thin sheet of light directed perpendicular to the optic axis

name: FLIP
def: Fluorescence loss in photobleaching; a method of determining whether two populations of fluorophore are in diffusive communication with one another by observing the decrease in brightness of one population when the other population is subjected to continuous photobleaching.

name: FRAP
def: Fluorescence loss in photobleaching; a method of determining the rate and extent of exchange between a localized population of fluorophore and a non-localized diffusible pool, by observing the rate of recovery of brightness of the localized population after photobleaching.

name: FRET
def: Fluorescence (or Forster) resonance energy transfer; a method of estimating the distance between two fluorophores by measuring the extent of non-radiative energy transfer between the two. Experimentally, this involves selective excitation of one while observing emission from the other.

name: SPIM
def: single (or selective) plane illumination.

name: CARS
def: coherent Raman anti-Stokes microscopy

name: OCT
def: optical coherence tomography; an interferometric method of imaging using back-scattered photons (elastic scattering)

name: secondary_electron imaging
def: image created using the electrons generated by ionization of a sample due to inelastic scattering of the primary beam of radiation

name: back-scattered_electron imaging
def: imaged formed using electrons undergoing elastic scattering at very high angles, with emission of characteristic X-rays

name: detection of current induced in the specimen
specimen_modifying_illumination
def: Illumination used for the purpose of inducing some observable change in the specimen during the course of an imaging session. This illumination may or may not be the same as the illumination used for imaging. Typically used in conjunction with live-cell imaging

name: slit-scanning illumination
def: illumination in the shape of a thin line that is swept over the field of view

name: slit-scan confocal microscopy
def: illumination and detection via a thin slit

name: array-scan confocal microscopy
def: Fixed array of sources focused to an array of spots that is swept over the specimen in raster fashion

name: visualization of contiguous regions
def: methods of visualization that differentiate between different regions or surfaces of the specimen based on contiguity

name: visualization by chemical attribute
def: methods of visualization that differentiate regions of the specimen on the basis of their chemical properties

name: shadowing and plating
def: visualization by depositing a label on the surface of a specimen uniformly (plating), or from a particular direction so that surface topography becomes visible (shadowing)

name: negative staining
def: visualization by exclusion of a stain in which the specimen is immersed; compare with \

name: fluorescent protein derived from Aequorea victoria
Blue fluorescent protein from Aequorea victoria
TexasRed
def: fluorophore with ex/em 589/615

name: Tetramethyl rhodamine (TRITC)
def: fluorophore derivative of rhodamine with ex/em 547/572

name: isolated subcellular component
def: A fragment of a cell, subcellular organelle, or macromolecular complex.

name: secondary electron generation
def: electrons generated by inelastic scattering of other radiation, the primary radiation.

name: critical_point dried specimen
def: specimen from which water has been removed by a process that avoids liquid-gas and solid-gas phase transitions.

name: unprocessed raw data
def: data as acquired, with no alterations that change the pixel values.

name: lyophilized specimen
def: specimen from which water has been removed by evaporation under vacuum at a temperature below freezing.

name: X-Rhodamine
def: fluorophore derivative of rhodamine with ex/em 580/605

name: serial block face SEM (SBFSEM)
def: A method of reconstructing 3D structure by combining serial sectioning with scanning EM.

name: source of contrast
def: The source of the variation in the imaged parameter across the field of view.

name: distribution of a specific nucleic acid sequence
differences in adsorption or binding of stain
boundaries between regions with different refractive index
differences in amount of elastic light scattering
differences in deposition of metal shadow
radiography
def: An imaging technique that uses high energy electromagnetic radiation, typically X-rays, as a source of illumination.

name: X-ray radiography
def: Radiography using X-rays

name: X-ray tomography
def: Tomography using X-ray illumination.

name: tomography
def: An imaging technique that creates virtual sections through the use of any kind of penetrating wave.

name: computed tomography
def: Tomography in which virtual sections are taken from multiple angles and the results are processed via tomographic reconstruction software to produce 2 or 3D images.

name: focussed ion beam scanning electron microscopy (FIB-SEM)
def: A method of reconstructing 3D structure by combining focussed ion beam milling to remove sucessive layers from a sample block with scanning EM to image the exposed surface between each milling step.

name: molecular_function
def: A molecular process that can be carried out by the action of a single macromolecular machine, usually via direct physical interactions with other molecular entities. Function in this sense denotes an action, or activity, that a gene product (or a complex) performs.

name: biological_process
def: A biological process is the execution of a genetically-encoded biological module or program. It consists of all the steps required to achieve the specific biological objective of the module. A biological process is accomplished by a particular set of molecular functions carried out by specific gene products (or macromolecular complexes), often in a highly regulated manner and in a particular temporal sequence.

name: kinase activity
def: Catalysis of the transfer of a phosphate group, usually from ATP, to a substrate molecule.

name: curation status specification
def: The curation status of the term. The allowed values come from an enumerated list of predefined terms. See the specification of these instances for more detailed definitions of each enumerated value.

name: quality
def: A dependent entity that inheres in a bearer by virtue of how the bearer is related to other entities

name: is anatomical entity
def: This property only applies to anatomical entities.
